bibl.title: Letter from L. O. Woodward to P. F. Murphy, September 21, 1923

div1.p: Woodward states that a passenger was taken on board ship. He describes the patient's symptoms, care, and subsequent death at Las Animas Hospital of malaria.

div1.head: Letter from L. O. Woodward to P. F. Murphy, September 21, 1923
div1.opener:
COPY
Subject:
JAS. E. ROUDABUSH.
Medical Department
S.S. “SARAMACCA”,
New Orleans, La.
Sept. 21st, 1923.
Dr. P. F. Murphy,
Port Medical Officer,
United Fruit Co.,
New Orleans, La.
Dear Doctor:
div1.p:
I desire to make a statement concerning the case of Jas. E.
Roudabush, a consular passenger, whom we were forced to take on board ship
at Puerto Barrios by the American Consul against both the will of the Cap-
tain and myself. Upon examining patient I saw he was physically unfit to
make voyage, although he had no temperature and gave no history of any past
illness. A small macular lesion was noted on glans penis at junction of
mucus membrane with gland which made me suspicious of venereal disease.
Patient was rejected for passage and Purser carried him back to American
Consul, who said we must either carry patient or ship would be fined. So
patient was placed in room to himself on aft deck where he was treated and
taken care of until he was removed from ship in Havana; the patient being
in more or less of a stupor all the time, I was unable to get any satis-
factory history from him, which made the diagnosis of the case all the more
complicated. It was only the last day while on board the ship that patient
told me he had fever eleven days and diarrhea five days before leaving
Barrios. At no time during the three days' voyage from Barrios to Havana
did patient's temperature go over 99 1/2 except evening of arrival at Havana
it registered 101.

His pulse was always very weak and rapid, registering from 110 to
144. He had a lethargic facial expression and his skin a yellowish lemon-
like color, becoming a deeper yellow each day. There was an incontinence
of urine and feces. Upon pressure over the abdomen there was severe pain
- 2 -
over entire bowels, but no masses were felt. There was no nausea or vomiting
until last day of voyage. As to treatment, I gave very little medicine as I
thought patient's condition was one where comfort and supportive measures
should be used instead of drugs. Quinine was administered the second day as
was a mixture of paregoric and bismuth to check the diarrhea. Cold fruit
drinks and ice cream was given patient as nourishment in hopes that he would
gain strength.

Upon arrival at Havana our ship was quarantined for two hours while
it was being decided as to what disposition would be made of patient. Our
agent at Havana had him removed from ship to Las Animos Hospital at seven
o'clock, P. M., and we were informed that he died at eigh thirty o'clock
same evening, cause of death being given as malarial fever.

Assuring you that every attention was accorded Jas. A. Roudabush
that was possible while he was ill upon this vessel, I beg to remain
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, (Signed) L. O. Woodward,
Ship's Doctor.
